LeadPara.Para: Murray Moss's impact on the design world is virtually immeasurable. During its reign, his namesake shop-cum-gallery in SoHo, which opened in 1994 and closed in 2012, defined avant-garde good taste. Moss blurred the lines between art and design and reinvented visual merchandising, displaying everything from an 18th-century Nymphenburg figurine to a kaleidoscopic array of Maarten Baas Clay chairs inside massive vitrines within the immaculate white space. After almost 50 years in Manhattan, the 68-year-old, who now runs his own design and retail consulting firm, moved to a traditional clapboard house in Connecticut last year with his partner in life and business, Franklin Getchell, with whom he has also co-authored a new Rizzoli book, out this April, documenting the cultural influence of the Moss store. But to this day, Moss still considers his childhood growing up in the suburbs of '60s Chicago to be his most formative period.

TailParas.Para: When his father insisted on installing electric hand-dryers and Borax soap dispensers in the bathrooms of their home, his mother agreed, provided their decorator could enamel them in pink and turquoise pastels. ''To me, that epitomized what Modernism should be,'' Moss says. ''I've been fascinated by the juxtaposition of the industrial and the decorative ever since.''

Article.Art: 1. One of my happiest moments was walking through sheep meadows on holiday in West Sussex in 2005. I usually hate being outdoors, but this was so peaceful. 2. Me in the library of our house in Hamden, Conn. I look skeptical, probably because I never thought I'd end up surrounded by knotty wood and William Morris-esque wallpaper. 3. This 1874 portrait by the Spanish painter Pere Borrell del Caso, ''Escaping Criticism,'' reminds me of the power of deception and illusion. I saw it in a bank in Madrid. 4. I'm the intense ballerina on the right. In spite of the bouffant satin blouse, I do think I have an inner strength -- and I still recognize that chutzpah in myself today. 5. In 1973, I bought this Rolex as a gift for Franklin. We take turns wearing it and have been swapping it back and forth for almost 50 years. 6. I got this souvenir -- an eraser -- at Stonehenge's surprisingly fabulous gift shop. Ironic, I thought, because you're never going to erase Stonehenge. 7. Seventeenth-century figurines are the devil to Modernism, but I fell in love with Nymphenburg's sculptures while traveling through Bavaria in the early 2000s. I later exhibited them at the store and got hate mail from clients saying: ''What is this garbage?'' I keep my glassware and porcelain collection in this pantry, a cabinet of wonder much like a case at the Moss store. I love Hella Jongerius ceramics, early Baccarat and Lobmeyr. 9. A triptych of Warholian florals from my 2015 redesign of the Museum of Fine Arts, Houston's gift shop. I wanted to create a space that felt totally separate from the galleries. 10. I own several works from 20th-century photographer Weegee's midcentury series of distortions, including this one of Marilyn Monroe. I love how he takes something about a person and heightens it. 11. I sold Sarah Schwartz's sculpted soaps at the store in the late '90s; they're shaped to resemble the Venus of Willendorf, but, unlike the original, these will be touched, reduced and dissolved. 12. While I was working with Meissen, the oldest hard-clay porcelain factory in the West, I found this lobster tureen from 1790. It reminds me of my childhood, because my mother kept a kitschy lobster dish in our sunroom. 13. In 2005, I had Kim Hastreiter of Paper Magazine guest-curate a show of hooked rugs from the Oakland, Calif.-based nonprofit art center Creative Growth. This one, of a woman drinking tea, was my favorite. 14. Tejo Remy's ''You Can't Lay Down Your Memory'' (1991), from a 1995 exhibition at the store. 15. Franklin in 1986 in Anguilla. When we were young, we liked choosing age-inappropriate places where mostly old people went. 16. This was the first diorama I made at Moss. It had a skeletal theme: The Castiglioni lamp resembles protruding bones, Jurgen Bey's chairs look like they've been eaten by an animal, and inside the small glass case there's a taxidermied bird.
